title: E based on delta G of hydrogen fuel cell

content.description: <math alttext="2 H 2 gas plus O 2 gas react to produce 2 H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction equals negative 474 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>474</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>
content.question: Electrode Half-Reaction Standard Reduction Potential <math alttext="in volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(V)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Cathode <math alttext="O 2 gas plus 4 H with positive one charge aqueous plus 4 electrons react to produce 2 H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="question mark" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>?</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> Anode <math alttext="2 H with a positive one charge aqueous plus 2 electrons produce H 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> 0.00 The operation of a hydrogen fuel cell under standard conditions relies on the chemical reaction represented above. The table provides the relevant reduction half-reactions and the standard reduction potentials. Based on the information given, which of the following equations can be used to calculate the standard reduction potential, in volts, of the half-reaction occurring at the cathode?

choices.label: <math alttext="E naught sub reduction of the cathode equals the fraction negative 474 over 4 times 96,500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></msub><mtext>(cathode)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>474</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mn>96</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>500</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E naught sub reduction of the cathode equals the negative of the fraction negative 474,000 over 4 times 96,500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></msub><mtext>(cathode)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>474</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>000</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mn>96</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>500</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E naught sub reduction of the cathode equals the fraction 4 times 96,500 over 474" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></msub><mtext>(cathode)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mn>96</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>500</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>474</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E naught sub reduction of the cathode equals the negative of the fraction 4 times 96,500 over negative 474,000" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></msub><mtext>(cathode)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mn>96</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>500</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>474</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>000</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="E naught sub reduction of the cathode equals the negative of the fraction negative 474,000 over 4 times 96,500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></msub><mtext>(cathode)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>474</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>000</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mn>96</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>500</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
